abstract: New York City Health Dept publishes regulations, set to take effect in August, requiring that fish served raw, undercooked or marinated raw must first be frozen; restaurateurs across city post few objections, revealing that practice of using flash-frozen fish has been longstanding practice, even in popular sushi restaurants, as a way of removing parasites and bacteria.
lead_paragraph: A regulation by New York City’s health department, to take effect in August, will require that fish served raw must be frozen before serving it to guard against parasites.

headline.main: New York City Requires Restaurants to Freeze Raw Fish Before Serving
headline.print_headline: Restaurants Must Freeze All Raw Fish, City Requires

snippet: A regulation by New York City’s health department, to take effect in August, will require that fish served raw must be frozen before serving it to guard against parasites.
